etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. From French méthylamine from methyl + amine

definitions: Each of the three compounds that can be formed by replacing one or more of the hydrogen atoms in ammonia with a methyl group or groups; especiallyCH₃ NH₂ (monomethylamine), a colourless, flammable gas with a fishy or ammonia-like odour.
